origin: Late Old English (in plot (sense 3 of the noun)), of unknown origin. The sense ‘secret plan’, dating from the late 16th century, is associated with Old French complot ‘dense crowd, secret project’, the same term being used occasionally in English from the mid 16th century Compare with plat.

definitions.definition: A plan made in secret by a group of people to do something illegal or harmful.
definitions.example: there's a plot to overthrow the government

definitions.definition: The main events of a play, novel, movie, or similar work, devised and presented by the writer as an interrelated sequence.
definitions.example: the plot consists almost entirely of a man and woman falling in love

definitions.definition: A small piece of ground marked out for a purpose such as building or gardening.
A graph showing the relation between two variables.
definitions.example: Interpreting that information is not like interpreting a simple plot or graph.

definitions.definition: Secretly make plans to carry out (an illegal or harmful action)
definitions.example: the two men are serving sentences for plotting a bomb campaign

definitions.definition: Devise the sequence of events in (a play, novel, movie, or similar work)
definitions.example: she would plot a chapter as she drove

definitions.definition: Mark (a route or position) on a chart.
definitions.example: he started to plot lines of ancient sites
